registration.sv: n find the course online here: <a href="https://divingintoradicalcreativity.aalto.fi/register/"

content.fi:
Welcome to "Diving into Radical Creativity," an innovative open online course breaking free from traditional learning boundaries. Its non-linear structure enables you to navigate a diverse content landscape, crafting a personalized learning journey. Across five chapters covering introduction, individual, process, collective, and impact aspects of radical creativity, this introductory course moves beyond theory and scientific findings on creativity research. It includes multiple case studies showcasing powerful examples of radical creativity.
These chapters enable learners to answer fundamental questions: What does radical creativity mean? How can I become more creative? How can I use creativity in my studies, work, and growing as a person? What are the stages of the creative process? How can creativity address challenges? How is creativity promoted in cooperation? How does radical creativity shape the world?
This self-directed course exceeds mere academia; through real-life activities and assignments, it is an opportunity to develop confidence in idea generation, experimentation, and learning from diverse experiences. Designed for both undergraduates and postgraduates, "Diving into Radical Creativity" promises an engaging, practical exploration of radical creativity in varied contexts.
Welcome to a transformative journey, inviting you to dive into the realm of radical creativity.

name.en: Introduction to Large Language Models, Online teaching

learningOutcomes.fi:
The student forms a conceptual understanding of
language models and large language models. The student understands key
principles underlying the current large language models. The student
understands the effect of prompting on large language models and can engineer
prompts for large language models to improve output quality. The student knows
of issues related to large language models such as hallucination, bias,
privacy, and security.

name.fi: Special Course in Human Neuroscience: Brain Circuits: Principles of neuroanatomy in neuroimaging and brain stimulation, Luento-opetus

prerequisites.fi: Two out of these courses to be already passed: Physiology (NBE-C2201); Structure and Operation of the Human Brain (NBE-E4210); Medical Imaging (NBE-E4020); Cognitive Neuroscience (NBE-E4225); The students should have general knowledge of gross brain anatomy and the basics of MRI, but also an idea about other neuroimaging technologies and brain stimulation techniques. Working knowledge in image processing would be useful.

prerequisites.en: Two out of these courses to be already passed: Physiology (NBE-C2201); Structure and Operation of the Human Brain (NBE-E4210); Medical Imaging (NBE-E4020); Cognitive Neuroscience (NBE-E4225);The students should have general knowledge of gross brain anatomy and the basics of MRI, but also an idea about other neuroimaging technologies and brain stimulation techniques. Working knowledge in image processing would be useful.

learningOutcomes.fi:
·         To appreciate the differences and similarities between human and non-human primate brain anatomy

·         To get acquainted with the Harvard–Oxford Atlas (HOA), basics of morphometric analytics

·         To identify structures of human anatomy in the MRI 

·         To utilize tools for choosing cortical targets intended for brain stimulation treatments

·         To apply the neuroanatomy knowledge earned in this course in personalized medicine utilizing neuroimaging tools 

·         To identify the main brain networks, namely cognitive, affective, and/or autonomic, affected in neurological and psychiatric disorders

·         To know how to learn the basics for applying transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) to humans for mapping purposes

·         Elaborate upon an example of each brain network

literature.en: The study material will be based on the lectures, the learning diaries each student is keeping, scientific articles suggested by lecturers or found by students and on book(s) depending on their availability.

content.sv: Homologies between humans and nonhuman species;· The Harvard–Oxford Atlas (HOA) comparative neuroanatomical framework in morphometric analysis, connectivity and multimodal neuroimaging;· Aspects of brain anatomy in human clinical and comparative brain stimulation research contexts;· Special topics will include neuroimaging in clinical assessment and diagnosis, and utilization of neural networks and connectomics for more precise brain stimulation· Classical vs. current methods of understanding comparative brain anatomy· Advantages and limitations of current imaging tools, tailored in the context of brain stimulation and TMS in particular.· Hands-on experimental work for TMS
